Yes, blockchain technology can be used to identify users who post properties, buy or sell on a real estate portal. One way to do this is by implementing a decentralized identity management system that utilizes blockchain technology.

Here's an example of how it could work:

1. Each user would have a unique digital identity stored on the blockchain. This identity would contain information such as their name, address, and other identifying information.
2. When a user wants to post a property for sale, they would sign the transaction with their private key. This would verify their identity and allow the transaction to be recorded on the blockchain.
3. The transaction would include information about the property, such as its location, price, and other relevant details.
4. When another user wants to buy the property, they would also need to verify their identity using their private key. This would ensure that only authorized individuals are able to participate in the transaction.
5. Once the transaction is complete, it would be recorded on the blockchain and both the buyer and the seller would have a permanent record of the transaction.

This is just a basic example of how blockchain technology can be used to verify the identities of users on a real estate portal. In a real-world scenario, the implementation would be more complex and would require a deeper understanding of blockchain technology and its various use cases.
